text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.

Brazilian imports of capital goods and primary resources, which doubled to $37.3 billion in 1996 from $18 billion in 1993, increased capacity in some industrial sectors but also replaced much of domestic production.

Government advisors on the restructuring of the power sector are proposing to change the concession periods for hydroelectric plants to between five to 15 years in order to maintain power generating costs at current levels.
-- CARDOSO BLAMES STATES FOR LAND INVASIONS
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has accused state governments and the Public Minstry of allowing invasions of landed properties by landless peasants.
-- GOVT TO BACK REGIONAL MINIMUM SALARIES
The government is expected to back a proposal for the introduction of a minimum salary the amount of which may vary according to region.
-- GOVT WANTS TO CREATE TWO MINIMUM SALARIES

The Labor Ministry would like to see two different minimum salaries, one lower one for domestic employees, pensioners and public workers, and another higher salary for employees in the private sector.
-- MAGALHAES WINS AND PROMISES FASTER REFORMS
Senator Antonio Carlos Magalhaes has won the presidency of the Brazilian Senate, promising to speed up voting on constitutional reforms and the re-election amendment.
-- Reuters has not verified the stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
-- Simona de Logu, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 507 4151
